content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I agree with this little exercise it's simple but still allows you to think straight I think it can be good.
Looks goood!

Je ne vois pas en quoi traduire des formules mathématiques en du code donne à un problème un niveau difficile. Ici il s'agit juste de suivre la piste lovelace, bernouilli. Il n'y a pas de recherche d'un algo ou d'une stratégie juste de la traduction de math => c'est un niveau facile en terme de codage, moyen sur le sujet abordé.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: le puzzle est pas mal, pas trop complexe mais pas facile non plus

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: accept this contribution

The puzzle looks intressting but seeing there are only 21 different input possibilities, im temped to go to oeis and just write the first 3 terms find the series and hard code the problem. 

I recomand you to make the upper limit bigger or changing some other fue thing. 

I haven't tried to solve it yet, but I'll come back here when I have.

But looks intresting

Is this puzzle solvable in other programming languages available on CodinGame? I believe not all languages can support arbitrarily large numbers like Python does.

The usual advice is to limit the absolute value of output to below 2**64.
The banner and title are clues. This is Episode 1, leading up to modular power sums with astronomical values of n.

I was concerned that by doing this, a modular reduction of successive modular powers might bypass the complexity barrier without needing Faulhaber/Bernoulli. But with this 2**64 limitation, the challenge doesn't lose any of its power :D. Thanks for the advice!

After solving it and testing you can easily getting the value up to N = 100-300 So i can recommand you to make the upper limit 100 or 200 and just add some fue higger number. 

But a realy good probleme it make me learn a new thing Faulhaber polynomial.

Would you please state the reasons for your approval and not just mention that you accept a contribution in the future?

Also, I notice that you've approved 6 contributions in a row. have you really tried to solve the contributions and write your own solutions before you approve them? Please don't approve them if you have not done so yet.

I don't necessarily disagree, especially since the title itself is a clue as to what needs to be found (and understood). I had initially rated this problem as "easy" and followed the advice of experienced CodinGamers to increase its difficulty level to "hard." I have just reclassified it as "medium."
If Episode 1 is approved, there will be an Episode 2, which will demand more creativity.
I disagree with @FoxAlfabravo_101. It is more than just the translation of formulas to code. The player still has to understand the maths involved in order to know what to search.

To further elaborate my view, one cannot merely look at the coding part while discarding the research part when determining the difficulty level.

* The mentioning of "Ada Lovelace's G Note" in Goal section may lead to the player to discover Bernoulli numbers.

* But does the player necessarily know how to proceed forwards? Especially one without a relatively strong maths background?

* OK, let's assume they then get the idea of searching power sums and discovering Faulhaber's formula, and implement it in code.

* Then they may find that they face a timeout issue because of the large powers. Optimisation requires a search for another algorithm.

At least three pieces of knowledge are required to solve this puzzle.

As at this moment, this puzzle's success rate is 38%. Out of 319 Medium difficulty puzzles, 36 puzzles had a lower success rate than this puzzle. As the number of players who have started the puzzle is still small, the rate may still fluctuate quite a bit. If after a period the success rate has become relatively stable and is much lower than the current rate, one should seriously consider bumping up the difficulty level to Hard.

I agree with your analysis. I adopted a more conciliatory tone toward FoxAlphabravo’s type of critique because I wanted my puzzle to be approved. However, this isn’t simply about translating mathematical formulas. There is genuine work involved in researching, discovering, understanding, and piecing together unconventional elements (like in Westicles' Million Digits of Pi), with a path implicitly shaped by the increasing complexity wall.

As for determining the final difficulty of the puzzle, I agree—let's wait until a sufficient portion of the community has tackled it.
You could also in the output section change to "The integer [[S_n]] mod 2^53

Hello fellow citizen. Thank you for your upvote and for your advice.

I'm glad you enjoyed the puzzle and that it led you to encounter Faulhaber's polynomials.

It's fascinating to discover and programmatically build direct calculation formulas for power sums, and then evaluate them within the same program.

Faulhaber is just an appetizer; he is the precursor to the Bernoulli revolution. I'm thinking about how to stage Episode 2, especially in terms of application and gamification. But the idea is to go much further, using the best methods available today to calculate Bernoulli numbers (Harvey's algorithm). Beyond the application of power sums, this topic connects with the Euler-Maclaurin formula and the Riemann Zeta function.

From an algorithmic perspective, it’s challenging in terms of complexity. There’s also a lot of implementation related to prime numbers and modular arithmetic, involving extended Euclidean algorithms and the Chinese Remainder Theorem, which is fascinating and a valuable skill set for a computer scientist.

That said, I'm not sure the topic will get the green light within 27 days, as it might be too math-heavy for some. 

I look forward to seeing you in Episode II, which I'll probably put in the contribution queue next week.

For the tests in Episode 1, I'll update with N = [9, 19, 29, 39, 49, 69, 99, 139]. Around 140, the basic recurrence for calculating Bernoulli numbers starts to struggle, even with memoization. And I want to avoid pushing the player further than this initial discovery step in Episode 1.

If you think the puzzle looks good you can publish it in "Validation mode", because in WIP nobody can approve your puzzle. But yes mathy puzzle are really long to aprove.

Thank you for you explaination, I love to see the Episode II next week.
And for the memoisation, when i code it using list to memoize instead of the default python fonction it look quick until 400, but didn't test in coddinggame

Using a custom cache instead of functools memoization was definitely a great idea. Under the naive Bernoulli recurrence condition, we can go up to a magnitude of 512 within the timeout. I've updated the tests with jumps of 2^K.
I feel like just power of two +- 1 is not a strong test case, for me you should get a random odd number between each power to make this "more random test case"

Thank you for making the changes.

The difficulty looks like Hard to me because it seems quite mathy. How many episodes are you planning to create?

I marked it as 'Easy' by default, waiting for feedback, but it might actually be 'Medium' or even 'Hard' right from the start. If one has to solve it from scratch, you’d need to be a Pascal, Faulhaber, or Bernoulli. But today, with a bit of research on power sums, players will inevitably come across Faulhaber’s formulas and Bernoulli polynomials (cf. my ref to Ada Lovelace's G Note). From there, it’s less about designing from scratch and more about translating recurrence formulas into code. However, it still requires knowing how to manipulate arrays, work with recursion, and think about memoization.

Episode 2: It would be about exploring modular cycle detection, particularly related to some properties listed in [https://oeis.org/A031971](https://oeis.org/A031971) and [https://oeis.org/A014117](https://oeis.org/A014117). I have the ingredients, but I need to build something fun and non-trivial to solve. First, let’s see how Episode 1 turns out.
The mod should be way lower, languages that uses signed integers the max int is 2**63-1, in javascript it's 2**53-1
